content.text: Place the metre ruler on the pivot
Place the load P on the metre ruler with its centre at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark
Keeping P at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark, adjust the position of the metre ruler on the pivot so that the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced
Calculate, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, the distance \(a\) from the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot
Calculate, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, the distance \(b\) from the pivot to the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) end of the metre ruler

Repeat the steps above, placing the load P at the \(85.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(80.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(75.0 \text{cm}\) mark and \(70.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Record the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in Table 1.1
Plot a graph of \(a / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(b / \text{cm}\) (x-axis). Start the \(y\)-axis at \(a = 0.0 \text{cm}\). Start the \(x\)-axis at a suitable value for your results
Draw the best-fit line
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The weight \(W\) of the metre ruler is numerically equal to \(2\mathrm{G}\)
Calculate the weight \(W\) of the metre ruler
Suggest one practical reason why it is difficult to obtain accurate readings for \(a\) and \(b\)
In this experiment, you will determine the weight of a metre ruler using a balancing method
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Close the switch
Measure the current \(I\) in the circuit
Place the sliding contact \(\mathbf{C}\) at a distance \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{B}\)
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across length \(l\) of the resistance wire
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the resistance \(R\) of \(20.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire. Use the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
Repeat the procedure using \(l = 60.0 \text{cm}\) and \(l = 100.0 \text{cm}\)
Open the switch
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, \(\frac{R}{l}\) for each value of \(l\)
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
Write a conclusion about the relationship between \(R\) and \(l\)
Justify your conclusion by reference to your results
Look carefully at the values of \(\frac{R}{l}\) in Table 2.1
Use the values in Table 2.1 to estimate the resistance \(R_{2}\) of \(2.000 \text{m}\) of the resistance wire
Show your working
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a resistance wire
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Measure the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the illuminated object provided. Fig. 3.2 shows the height to be measured on your object
\(h_{\mathrm{O}} =\)
Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object
Move the screen slowly until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen
Measure the distance \(\nu\) between the centre of the lens and the screen
Record \(\nu\) in Table 3.1
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the magnification \(m\) using the equation \(m = \frac{\nu}{U}\)
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the height of the image \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\) formed on the screen
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the ratio \(\frac{h_{I}}{h_{\mathrm{O}}}\) , where \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) is the height of the object recorded in (a)
Repeat the procedure using \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\)
State whether your results agree with the suggestion. Justify your statement by reference to your results
statement
justification
Suggest how you would continue to use the same apparatus to test the suggestion that the magnification \(m\) is equal to the ratio \(\frac{h_{I}}{h_{O}}\)
A student suggests that the magnification \(m\) is equal to the ratio \(\frac{h_{I}}{h_{O}}\)
In this experiment, you will investigate the magnification of the image produced by a lens
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1 and Fig. 3.2
A student investigates the time taken for water to evaporate to dryness when heated from above
Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up. The power of the heater is constant
The following is also available:
supply of water at room temperature
• metre ruler
Plan an experiment to investigate how one factor affects the time taken for the water to evaporate
You are **not** required to do this investigation
You do **not** need to write about safety precautions
You should:
• state any additional apparatus required
• explain briefly how you would do the investigation
• state the key variables that you would keep constant
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion
